captions.text:
JOHN: Good morning, Hank, it's Tuesday. So
VidCon was fun - so fun, in fact, that I took

hardly any video except for this (audience
screaming).
JOHN: Hello, VidCon!

JOHN: Anyway, it was basically like that level
of sensory input for 72 straight hours, but

before VidCon, I was on a television program
called "The Colbert Report," which meant makeup.

JOHN: So, I am completely, really, super-into
getting my makeup done.
MAKEUP ARTIST: You are?
JOHN: Have I told you this yet?
MAKEUP ARTIST (laughing): No.
JOHN: I'm John, by the way.
MAKEUP ARTIST: John, I'm Bridget.

JOHN: And, yeah, I think - I had my makeup
done on the whole - the whole time I was on
the movie tour.
BRIDGET: Okay.

JOHN: Like, first thing in the morning, then
they'd touch it up all day long.
BRIDGET: Right.

JOHN: I just looked so good. I felt so good
about myself.
(Bridget laughs.)
JOHN: I'm not even kidding.
BRIDGET (laughing): That's awesome.

JOHN (to Hank): So while Bridget does my makeup,
Hank, a few makeup thoughts. I confess that

in high school, I was one of those guys who
was like, "You don't need to wear makeup.

You're beautiful just the way you are." Meanwhile,
of course, I was covering my body in carefully

selected clothes every morning, showing that
on some level, I did understand that humans

generally don't present themselves in public
"just the way they are."

Now obviously, TV makeup is different from
everyday makeup, but here's what I like about

makeup. One, it feels good. It feels good
to touch your face gently and kindly. Two,

it's like really beautiful armor because it
makes me feel more confident and, somehow,

kind of protected as I go through my day.
It's sort of like wearing my favorite outfit,
except I can do it every day.

Three, Hank, as you know, I am a massive hypochondriac,
so I don't like to touch my face because that's

how disease spreads. But I find that I actually
touch my face less when I'm wearing makeup

because my face is not, like, dry and itchy
and et cetera.

Four, I like the way I look. It's pretty simple,
actually. Hank, when I was younger, I basically

thought that women wore makeup for men, which
speaks to a sick and very deep part of the

patriarchy in which men imagine that women
orient themselves toward attracting men, instead

of having, like, meaning and pleasure inside
their own lives that has nothing to do with
dudes.

But when I wear makeup, I genuinely don't
derive pleasure from thinking about how I'll

look to people watching me on TV or whether
it will make me more attractive to other people

- I just like the way I look. It makes me
happy. Now, of course, lots of people don't

like wearing makeup, which is totally cool,
but I do!

That noted, I'm probably not going to be wearing
makeup on a daily basis, partly because I'm

lazy, partly because I am tragically un-immune
to social conventions, and partly because

I've been totally spoiled by having my makeup
done by amazing professionals like Bridget.

But this whole experience has made me a tremendous
fan of makeup, and also of the YouTube makeup

tutorial, so I put some links to my favorites
in the doobly-doo. And Hank, I also have to

say that I think you are super-cool for having
worn makeup in high school.
Okay, now it's time for my big reveal!

JOHN: Do I look all right? Do I look like
my regular self, but better?
SARAH: Mm-hmm. Yeah.
JOHN: Perfect.

JOHN: Hank, congratulations on VidCon. I hope
you're getting some sleep. I will see you
on Friday.

comments.text:
An open letter to the male people of the world: 
If you see me wearing makeup and would like to compliment me don't say "I 
think you're the prettiest without makeup" cause even if you think that, I 
just spend half an hour on that and now I'm just insulted. I'm not even 
joking, the best compliment I ever received was "you cat eye is on point. 
It's very even and flatters your eye shape" because that shit is hard and I 
do not wear makeup often so when I do it right I want some god damn credit. 
﻿
comments.author: NotTotallyHopeless

comments.text:
This started as a communication between John and Hank because they lived 
far away and wanted to still be able to talk. This was Brotherhood 2.0. 
They challenged themselves to only talk through video, not through text. 
During that time, they gained a following for themselves, so they continued 
doing the videos in the same style even after the Brotherhood 2.0 year was 
over. This is actually video communication to each other -- they're just 
telling each other things -- but lots of people are also watching.
comments.author: Learning FTW

comments.text:
I get the meaning and goodness of the message "I wear make-up for myself" 
but it's not really true. Not to get all psych 101 but the reason you think 
that you wear make-up because it makes you feel good is because you 
internalized the idea that other people put in your head. Not that this 
should stop anyone from wearing make-up since we wear pants every day (if 
we're unlucky) for the exact same reason but it's worth knowing that yeah, 
you wear make-up for other people and for your own sake, and that's okay. ﻿
comments.author: Vincent de Verdier

comments.text:
I hate to say it, but this video makes me feel uncomfortable. I understand 
that many women use makeup as a form of self expression, but I firmly 
believe that the vast majority of women wear it for fear of baring their 
natural faces to the world. I don't wear any makeup from day to day, but I 
feel absolutely compelled to when I go to clubs or parties. And I'm 
relatively lucky in my level of self confidence; I'm only twenty, and yet 
many of the young women I know already feel serious anxiety over leaving 
the house without makeup. This becomes more than just a confidence issue 
when you consider the extent to which a makeup habit can add up financially 
in the long run. While I think the sexes should be equal, I would prefer 
that the playing field be leveled through raising women up rather than 
through dragging men down. ﻿
comments.author: mirandamd13

comments.text:
I think that it may begin as a form of self-expression or because you want 
to look better for yourself or whatever it is, but then without it, you 
feel too exposed, too weak... kind of like drug addiction, come to think of 
it.
And yes, it is much better to raise up the people who are having trouble 
than to make both sides have that trouble.
comments.author: Learning FTW

comments.text:
I'm going to politely disagree. I go bare faced most days, and I too wear 
makeup when I go out to a party or something, but personally I enjoy that 
feeling. I like getting dressed up and going out and feeling confident. And 
that's not to say I don't feel confident normally, it's just that when I'm 
discussing economics with my professor it's a different type of confidence 
than going out all dolled up. I also find I usually just put on makeup on a 
Sunday afternoon when I'm sitting in and reading a book, just because I 
want to paint something on my face.

comments.text:
I didn't suggest it was narrow minded. I was shocked at how much men and 
women misunderstand each others ways. 

Just Because something is said in a YouTube comment doesn't mean it's 
looking for an argument, starting a sexist battle or criticizing someone. 
Sometimes a comment is just a simple comment.
comments.author: candice black

comments.text:
Actually, yeah, they do. It's not a narrow-minded assumption either, even 
though it's not very true. The thought process is based on the notion that 
wearing makeup makes you attractive to the opposite sex, which attracts 
more suitors. And in most cases, it's undeniable that this is at least a 
little bit true. However, what John is saying here is that the process of 
wearing makeup to make oneself aesthetically pleasing is done for the same 
reason that you wear a shirt because you like that shirt. You don't see it 
24/7 when it's on yourself, but it brings you pleasure because it adjusts 
your appearance in a way that suits YOU.
comments.author: javalin597

comments.text: now you know why women wear makeup. its great ain't it?﻿
comments.author: Izzy Carshuen (IzzyGale)

comments.text:
I recently was trying to explain to someone who told me I didn't need to 
wear makeup, why I like to wear it. Personally I love putting it on, it is 
cathartic for me and I can play with colors so it is my way of painting for 
15 minutes every morning when I wouldn't otherwise have time to touch a 
canvas. If I did wear makeup to impress men I'd go for a more natural look 
but I wear it because I just love it. It is nice to hear from a guy who has 
discovered why makeup can be so much fun.﻿
comments.author: Insanitydivided by .Zero

comments.text: Wait....why did Hank wear makeup in highschool lol? Please do elaborate. ﻿
comments.author: Dustin D.

comments.text:
Well I'm glad that all you people criticizing John and saying that you 
don't wear makeup are confident with your appearance and can feel happy 
going about your day without makeup on. For those of us with 
anxiety/confidence issues, wearing makeup is the best way to feel confident 
and personally I would be a nervous wreck going to school without makeup on 
because of my anxiety and I'd feel like every person who looked in my 
general direction was judging me.﻿
comments.author: Noelle

comments.text:
I completely relate to you. I also have an anxiety disorder which makes me 
feel like I am not good enough or that people are always judging me. 
Because of my anxiety, I am pretty shy. Makeup gives me that chance to 
express myself without actually having to verbalize it! And, truth be told, 
I feel way prettier when i wear makeup.  Whenever I don't wear makeup to 
school or, hell, even to the mall, I feel like every single person is 
judging me and about 8 times out of 10 it will induce a panic attack. Some 
people just need to understand that I wear makeup for ME! Not anyone else.
comments.author: LeyLey127

comments.text:
I'm going to be honest, I know most girls wear makeup for themselves of 
course, but I honestly only wear it when I'm trying to look good for guys. 
I know that sounds horrible or whatever but that's just me and I shouldn't 
be judged for it. I hate applying makeup but if I'm going to see a guy I'm 
interested in that day I will suck it up and wear it. But I don't wear it 
everyday, cause I don't see him everyday. When I'm out just chilling I'm 
makeup free. ﻿
comments.author: Des

comments.text: John is my favorite person ever.﻿
comments.author: Ana Duvergel

comments.text:
This is what I wish people would get. I spend 20 minutes every day doing my 
makeup alone in the bathroom with the door shut. now this makes my brother; 
who doesn't get the concept that we have like 2 other bathrooms, very happy 
but that's beside the point. I stand there looking in the mirror for 20 
minutes putting stuff on my face because I like to, and I want to. it's 
peaceful, it's fun (at least for me) and it's relaxing. I do the same thing 
ever day but there's almost relief in that. My dad says that I should stop 
trying to impress people, and sure part of me is, but for the most part, I 
don't care if someone thinks I over did it on the blush or my lip color is 
too bright, I love it just the same.﻿
comments.author: Emily Z

comments.text: The purpose of makeup: to make the wearer feel better about themselves.﻿

comments.text:
Of course! If you like the way you look and feel, then don't let anyone 
tell you you can't. There's this mentality that when it comes to "feminine" 
practices such as wearing dresses or wearing makeup, you're either 
extremely demure and girly or you're not. I believe that it's a spectrum, 
and that wearing makeup does not in any way, shape, or form make a person 
less independent or strong. If it makes you happy, then do it!
